content.question: A rod is free to rotate on a horizontal surface about a pivot at its left end, as shown. Frictional forces are negligible. A force of magnitude <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> is exerted at the midpoint of the rod at an angle <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math>, where initially <math alttext="theta equals 45 degrees" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>θ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>45</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">°</mi></mstyle></math>. If the angle <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> is increased while keeping the location and magnitude of the force constant, which of the following graphs would correctly represent the torque exerted by the force as a function of <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> as it is increased from <math alttext="45 degrees" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>45</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">°</mi></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="90 degrees" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">°</mi></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: The figure shows the graph of a line in a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled theta, and the values 45 degrees through 90 degrees, in increments of 15 degrees, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled Torque. The line begins halfway up the vertical axis and moves linearly upward and to the right.

The figure shows the graph of a curve in a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled theta, and the values 45 degrees through 90 degrees, in increments of 15 degrees, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled Torque. The curve begins slightly more than halfway up the vertical axis and moves gradually upward and to the right. The curve is concave down.

The figure shows the graph of a line in a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled theta, and the values 45 degrees through 90 degrees, in increments of 15 degrees, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled Torque. The line begins halfway up the vertical axis and moves linearly downward and to the right and reaches a value of 0 at 90 degrees.

The figure shows the graph of a curve in a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled theta, and the values 45 degrees through 90 degrees, in increments of 15 degrees, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled Torque. The curve begins more than halfway up the vertical axis and moves gradually downward and to the right and levels off at 90 degrees. The curve is concave up.
